source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/setup/environments
title: Environments

Environments
The Phoenix app can be run in various notebook environments such as colab and SageMaker as well as be served via the terminal or a docker container
In the notebook
Run phoenix in the notebook as you run experiments
As a Container
Start a long-running collector
From the Terminal
Run phoenix via the CLI
Notebooks
To start phoenix in the notebook environment, run:
Copy
import
 phoenix 
as
 px




session 
=
 px
.
launch_app
()
This will start a local Phoenix server. You can initialize the phoenix server with various kinds of data (traces, inferences). Check out the 
API for details
When running Phoenix in the notebook, by default it does not persist your data.
Container
Container images are still actively being worked on. If you are interested in hosted phoenix, please get in touch!
Phoenix server images are available via 
Docker Hub
. The hosted phoenix server runs as a trace collector and can be used if you want observability for LLM traces via docker compose or simply want a long-running phoenix instance. Below are examples of how to run phoenix va Docker for a specific version.
First pull the image you want to run (note you can use the tag 
latest
 if you would just like the latest version)
Copy
docker
 
pull
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
Now you can run the image you pulled (note you must expose the port 
6006
 so you can view the UI).
Copy
docker
 
run
 
-p
 
6006:6006
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
The Phoenix UI will be available at 
localhost:6006
.
If you deploy the Phoenix server (collector) to a remote machine, you will have to make sure to configure the remote endpoint as the collector endpoint.
Set Endpoint Environment Variable
Copy
import
 os




os
.
environ
[
"PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT"
]
 
=
 
"http://123.456.789:6006"
Note that the above is only necessary if your application is running in a Jupyter notebook. If you are trying to deploy your application and have phoenix collect traces via a container, please consult the 
deployment guide.
Terminal
If you want to start a phoenix server to collect traces, you can also run phoenix directly from the command line
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
serve
This will start the phoenix server on port 6006. If you are running your instrumented notebook or application on the same machine, traces should automatically be exported to 
http://127.0.0.1:6006
 so no additional configuration is needed. However if the server is running remotely, you will have to modify the environment variable 
PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT
 to point to that machine (e.g. 
http://<my-remote-machine>:<port>
)
Note that this command has various configuration options such as 
--host
 and 
--port
. For example:
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
--port
 
1234
 
--host
 
0.0.0.0
 
serve
Previous
Setup
Next
Configuration
Last updated 
3 months ago

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/quickstart
title: Quickstart

Quickstart
The easiest way to run Phoenix is locally in your own computer. To launch Phoenix, use the following steps.
Install
Using pip
Using conda
Docker
app.phoenix.arize.com
Copy
pip
 
install
 
arize-phoenix
Copy
conda
 
install
 
-c
 
conda-forge
 
arize-phoenix
Phoenix server images are available via 
Docker Hub
 and can be used via 
docker compose 
or if you simply want a long-running phoenix instance to share with your team.
Copy
docker
 
pull
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
If you don't want to host an instance of Phoenix yourself or use a notebook instance, you can use a persistent instance provided on our site. Sign up for an Arize Phoenix account at 
https://app.phoenix.arize.com/login
For more details, see 
Hosted Phoenix
Launch Phoenix
Launching phoenix can be done in many ways depending on your use-case.
Command Line
Docker
Notebook
app.phoenix.arize.com
Launch your local Phoenix instance using:
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
serve
For details on customizing a local terminal deployment, see 
Terminal Setup
.
Launch the phoenix docker image using:
Copy
docker
 
run
 
-p
 
6006:6006
 
-p
 
4317:4317
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
This will expose the Phoenix UI and REST API on 
localhost:6006
 and exposes the gRPC endpoint for spans on 
localhost:4317
For more details on customizing a docker deployment, see 
Docker
Within your notebook, launch Phoenix using:
Copy
import
 phoenix 
as
 px


px
.
launch_app
()
By default, notebook instances do not have persistent storage, so your traces will disappear after the notebook is closed. See 
Persistence
 or use one of the other deployment options to retain traces.
Hosted Phoenix instances are always online. Nothing more to do here!
Connect your App
To collect traces from your application, you must configure an OpenTelemetry TracerProvider to send traces to Phoenix. The 
register
 utility from the 
phoenix.otel
 module streamlines this process.
Python
TypeScript
Notebook
app.phoenix.arize.com
If 
arize-phoenix
 is not installed in your python environment, you can use 
arize-phoenix-otel
 to quickly connect to your phoenix instance.
Copy
pip
 
install
 
arize-phoenix-otel
Connect your application to your instance using:
Copy
from
 phoenix
.
otel 
import
 register




# defaults to endpoint="http://localhost:4317"


register
(


  project_name
=
"my-llm-app"
, 
# Default is 'default'


  endpoint
=
"http://localhost:4317"
,  
# Sends traces using gRPC


)
  
You do not have to use phoenix.otel to connect to your phoenix instance, you can use OpenTelemetry itself to initialize  your OTEL connection. See
Using OTEL Python Directly
See 
Setup Tracing: Python
 for more details on configuration and setup
For setting up tracing and OpenTelemetry with TypeScript, see 
Setup Tracing: TS
Connect your notebook to Phoenix:
Copy
from
 phoenix
.
otel 
import
 register




# defaults to endpoint="http://localhost:4317"


register
(


  project_name
=
"my-llm-app"
, 
# Default is 'default'


  endpoint
=
"http://localhost:4317"
,  
# Sends traces using gRPC


)
 
If 
arize-phoenix
 is not installed in your python environment, you can use 
arize-phoenix-otel
 to quickly connect to your phoenix instance.
Copy
pip
 
install
 
arize-phoenix-otel
Connect your application to your cloud instance using:
Copy
import
 os


from
 phoenix
.
otel 
import
 register




# Add Phoenix API Key for tracing


os
.
environ
[
"OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_HEADERS"
]
 
=
 f
"api_key=
{PHOENIX_API_KEY}
"




# configure the Phoenix tracer


register
(


  project_name
=
"my-llm-app"
, 
# Default is 'default'


  endpoint
=
"https://app.phoenix.arize.com/v1/traces"
,


)
 
Your Phoenix API key can be found on the Keys section of your dashboard.
Next Steps
Trace
 a running application
Run 
evaluations
 on traces
Test changes to you prompts, models, and application via 
experiments
Previous
Arize Phoenix
Next
Hosted Phoenix

9 hours ago

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/tracing/how-to-tracing/manual-instrumentation/javascript
title: Instrument: TS

Instrument: TS
While Phoenix is heavily a Python-based Observability and Evaluation framework, it supports other languages like TypeScript / JavaScript
You can trace your NodeJS application over OpenTelemetry
Phoenix is written and maintained in Python to make it natively runnable in Python notebooks. However, it can be stood up as a trace collector so that your LLM traces from your NodeJS application (e.g., LlamaIndex.TS, Langchain.js) can be collected. The traces collected by Phoenix can then be downloaded to a Jupyter notebook and used to run evaluations (e.g., 
LLM Evals
, Ragas).
Getting Started
Instrumentation
 is the act of adding observability code to an app yourself.
If you‚Äôre instrumenting an app, you need to use the OpenTelemetry SDK for your language. You‚Äôll then use the SDK to initialize OpenTelemetry and the API to instrument your code. This will emit telemetry from your app, and any library you installed that also comes with instrumentation.
Phoenix natively supports automatic instrumentation provided by OpenInference. For more details on OpenInfernce, checkout the 
project
instrumentation setup
Dependencies
Install OpenTelemetry API packages:
Copy
npm
 
install
 
@opentelemetry/api
 
@opentelemetry/resources
 
@opentelemetry/semantic-conventions
Install OpenInference instrumentation packages. Below is an example of adding instrumentation for OpenAI as well as the semantic conventions for OpenInference.
Copy
npm
 
install
 
@arizeai/openinference-instrumentation-openai
 
@arizeai/openinference-semantic-conventions
Initialize the SDK
If you instrument a Node.js application install the 
OpenTelemetry SDK for Node.js
:
Copy
npm
 
install
 
@opentelemetry/sdk-node
Before any other module in your application is loaded, you must initialize the SDK. If you fail to initialize the SDK or initialize it too late, no-op implementations will be provided to any library that acquires a tracer or meter from the API.
Copy
/*instrumentation.ts*/


import
 { NodeSDK } 
from
 
'@opentelemetry/sdk-node'
;


import
 { ConsoleSpanExporter } 
from
 
'@opentelemetry/sdk-trace-node'
;


import
 { Resource } 
from
 
'@opentelemetry/resources'
;


import
 { SemanticResourceAttributes } 
from
 
'@opentelemetry/semantic-conventions'
;




const
 
sdk
 
=
 
new
 
NodeSDK
({


  resource
:
 
new
 
Resource
({


    [
SemanticResourceAttributes
.
SERVICE_NAME
]
:
 
'yourServiceName'
,


    [
SemanticResourceAttributes
.
SERVICE_VERSION
]
:
 
'1.0'
,


  })
,


  traceExporter
:
 
new
 
ConsoleSpanExporter
()
,


});

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/tracing/how-to-tracing/instrumentation
title: Auto Instrumentation

Auto Instrumentation
How OpenInference facilitates automatic instrumentation of applications.
In order to make a system observable, it must be 
instrumented
: That is, code from the system‚Äôs components must emit traces.
Phoenix natively supports collecting traces generated via OpenInference automatic instrumentation. Phoenix has pre-built auto-instrumentors for 
Python
 and 
TypeScript / JavaScript
.


Python
LlamaIndex, LangChain, DSPy, OpenAI, Bedrock, Mistral and more
TypeScript / JavaScript
OpenAI, LangChainjs

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/setup/environments
title: Environments

Environments
The Phoenix app can be run in various notebook environments such as colab and SageMaker as well as be served via the terminal or a docker container
In the notebook
Run phoenix in the notebook as you run experiments
As a Container
Start a long-running collector
From the Terminal
Run phoenix via the CLI
Notebooks
To start phoenix in the notebook environment, run:
Copy
import
 phoenix 
as
 px




session 
=
 px
.
launch_app
()
This will start a local Phoenix server. You can initialize the phoenix server with various kinds of data (traces, inferences). Check out the 
API for details
When running Phoenix in the notebook, by default it does not persist your data.
Container
Container images are still actively being worked on. If you are interested in hosted phoenix, please get in touch!
Phoenix server images are available via 
Docker Hub
. The hosted phoenix server runs as a trace collector and can be used if you want observability for LLM traces via docker compose or simply want a long-running phoenix instance. Below are examples of how to run phoenix va Docker for a specific version.
First pull the image you want to run (note you can use the tag 
latest
 if you would just like the latest version)
Copy
docker
 
pull
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
Now you can run the image you pulled (note you must expose the port 
6006
 so you can view the UI).
Copy
docker
 
run
 
-p
 
6006:6006
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
The Phoenix UI will be available at 
localhost:6006
.
If you deploy the Phoenix server (collector) to a remote machine, you will have to make sure to configure the remote endpoint as the collector endpoint.
Set Endpoint Environment Variable
Copy
import
 os




os
.
environ
[
"PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT"
]
 
=
 
"http://123.456.789:6006"
Note that the above is only necessary if your application is running in a Jupyter notebook. If you are trying to deploy your application and have phoenix collect traces via a container, please consult the 
deployment guide.
Terminal
If you want to start a phoenix server to collect traces, you can also run phoenix directly from the command line
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
serve
This will start the phoenix server on port 6006. If you are running your instrumented notebook or application on the same machine, traces should automatically be exported to 
http://127.0.0.1:6006
 so no additional configuration is needed. However if the server is running remotely, you will have to modify the environment variable 
PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT
 to point to that machine (e.g. 
http://<my-remote-machine>:<port>
)
Note that this command has various configuration options such as 
--host
 and 
--port
. For example:
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
--port
 
1234
 
--host
 
0.0.0.0
 
serve
Previous
Setup
Next
Configuration
Last updated 
3 months ago

Run phoenix via the CLI
Notebooks
To start phoenix in the notebook environment, run:
Copy
import
 phoenix 
as
 px




session 
=
 px
.
launch_app
()
This will start a local Phoenix server. You can initialize the phoenix server with various kinds of data (traces, inferences). Check out the 
API for details
When running Phoenix in the notebook, by default it does not persist your data.
Container
Container images are still actively being worked on. If you are interested in hosted phoenix, please get in touch!
Phoenix server images are available via 
Docker Hub
. The hosted phoenix server runs as a trace collector and can be used if you want observability for LLM traces via docker compose or simply want a long-running phoenix instance. Below are examples of how to run phoenix va Docker for a specific version.
First pull the image you want to run (note you can use the tag 
latest
 if you would just like the latest version)
Copy
docker
 
pull
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
Now you can run the image you pulled (note you must expose the port 
6006
 so you can view the UI).
Copy
docker
 
run
 
-p
 
6006:6006
 
arizephoenix/phoenix:latest
The Phoenix UI will be available at 
localhost:6006
.
If you deploy the Phoenix server (collector) to a remote machine, you will have to make sure to configure the remote endpoint as the collector endpoint.
Set Endpoint Environment Variable
Copy
import
 os




os
.
environ
[
"PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT"
]
 
=
 
"http://123.456.789:6006"
Note that the above is only necessary if your application is running in a Jupyter notebook. If you are trying to deploy your application and have phoenix collect traces via a container, please consult the 
deployment guide.
Terminal
If you want to start a phoenix server to collect traces, you can also run phoenix directly from the command line
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
serve
This will start the phoenix server on port 6006. If you are running your instrumented notebook or application on the same machine, traces should automatically be exported to 
http://127.0.0.1:6006
 so no additional configuration is needed. However if the server is running remotely, you will have to modify the environment variable 
PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT
 to point to that machine (e.g. 
http://<my-remote-machine>:<port>
)
Note that this command has various configuration options such as 
--host
 and 
--port
. For example:
Copy
python3
 
-m
 
phoenix.server.main
 
--port
 
1234
 
--host
 
0.0.0.0
 
serve

Setup
Next
Configuration

Can I persistdata in the notbook?

use_temp_dir
 flag to false in 
px.launch_app

.

How to configure phoenix

FAQ
Will hosted Phoenix be on the latest version of Phoenix?
On account creation, we will always use the latest version of Phoenix. We try to keep all instances of hosted Phoenix up to date and run upgrades for them when new versions are available. There will be a few minutes of downtime during these periods.
Data retention
We have a 30 day data retention policy. We are working on plans to offer a longer data retention period.
Sharing
Currently accounts are setup to be used specifically for one developer. We will be adding ways to share your traces with other developers on your team shortly!
Pricing
Hosted Phoenix is free for all developers. We will add a paid tier in the future which increases your data retention and also give you access to more storage.
Are there other demos available?
Yes. This demo and 
accompanying blog
 show how to deploy Phoenix via Docker/Kubernetes:

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/hosted-phoenix
title: Hosted Phoenix

Hosted Phoenix
We now offer a hosted version of Phoenix to make it easier for developers to use Phoenix to trace their LLM applications and avoid setting up infrastructure. You can use our Colab links to follow along.
Framework
Llamaindex
Colab
Llamaindex with Llamacloud
Colab
OpenAI
Colab
The main differences for Hosted Phoenix:
Hosted Phoenix runs the latest version of our open source package and gates access to your data behind API keys and user authentication.
You must create an account
You need to add an API key as an environment variable during tracing
You need to add an API key as an environment variable when using the Client SDK
We also use 3rd party analytics tools to measure usage of our application to improve our services.
How to create an account
Click signup on 
phoenix.arize.com
. We offer logins via Google, Github, and email. This account will use the same account credentials as your Arize account if you have one.
Tracing: How to send in your first trace
Get your API keys from your Phoenix application on the left hand side. 
Here's the full sample code for LlamaIndex and OpenAI instrumentation. You can see all of our automatic tracing options 
here
.
LlamaIndex
OpenAI
Install the following libraries
Copy
!pip install opentelemetry-sdk opentelemetry-exporter-otlp


!pip install "arize-phoenix[evals,llama-index]" "openai>=1" gcsfs nest-asyncio "openinference-instrumentation-llama-index>=2.0.0"
Use the following python code to start instrumentation.
Copy
from
 opentelemetry 
import
 trace 
as
 trace_api


from
 opentelemetry
.
exporter
.
otlp
.
proto
.
http
.
trace_exporter 
import
 OTLPSpanExporter


from
 opentelemetry
.
sdk 
import
 trace 
as
 trace_sdk


from
 opentelemetry
.
sdk
.
trace
.
export 
import
 SimpleSpanProcessor


from
 openinference
.
instrumentation
.
llama_index 
import
 LlamaIndexInstrumentor




# Setup authentication and endpoint


os
.
environ
[
"OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_HEADERS"
]
 
=
 f
"api_key=
{PHOENIX_API_KEY}
"


endpoint 
=
 
"https://app.phoenix.arize.com/v1/traces"




# Setup tracing with OpenTelemetry


span_phoenix_processor 
=
 
SimpleSpanProcessor
(
OTLPSpanExporter
(endpoint
=
endpoint))


tracer_provider 
=
 trace_sdk
.
TracerProvider
()


tracer_provider
.
add_span_processor
(span_processor
=
span_phoenix_processor)




# Start instrumentation


LlamaIndexInstrumentor
().
instrument
(tracer_provider
=
tracer_provider, skip_dep_check
=
True
)
Checkout our colab tutorial here:
Install the following libraries
Copy
pip
 
install
 
arize-otel
 
openinference-instrumentation-openai
 
openai

arize-otel
, which sets up OpenTelemetry tracing with Hosted Phoenix. Run the following code to start instrumentation.
Copy
import
 os


from
 arize_otel 
import
 register_otel
,
 Endpoints


from
 openinference
.
instrumentation
.
openai 
import
 OpenAIInstrumentor




# Setup OTEL tracing for hosted Phoenix


# Endpoints.HOSTED_PHOENIX = "https://app.phoenix.arize.com"


PHOENIX_API_KEY 
=
 os
.
environ
[
"PHOENIX_API_KEY"
]


register_otel
(


    endpoints
=
[Endpoints.HOSTED_PHOENIX],


    api_key
=
PHOENIX_API_KEY


)




# Turn on instrumentation for OpenAI


OpenAIInstrumentor
().
instrument
()

FAQ
Will hosted Phoenix be on the latest version of Phoenix?
On account creation, we will always use the latest version of Phoenix. We try to keep all instances of hosted Phoenix up to date and run upgrades for them when new versions are available. There will be a few minutes of downtime during these periods.
Data retention
We have a 30 day data retention policy. We are working on plans to offer a longer data retention period.
Sharing
Currently accounts are setup to be used specifically for one developer. We will be adding ways to share your traces with other developers on your team shortly!
Pricing
Hosted Phoenix is free for all developers. We will add a paid tier in the future which increases your data retention and also give you access to more storage.
Are there other demos available?
Yes. This demo and 
accompanying blog
 show how to deploy Phoenix via Docker/Kubernetes:
Previous
Quickstart

User Guide

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/hosted-phoenix
title: Hosted Phoenix

Hosted Phoenix
We now offer a hosted version of Phoenix to make it easier for developers to use Phoenix to trace their LLM applications and avoid setting up infrastructure. You can use our Colab links to follow along.
Framework
Llamaindex
Colab
Llamaindex with Llamacloud
Colab
OpenAI
Colab
The main differences for Hosted Phoenix:
Hosted Phoenix runs the latest version of our open source package and gates access to your data behind API keys and user authentication.
You must create an account
You need to add an API key as an environment variable during tracing
You need to add an API key as an environment variable when using the Client SDK
We also use 3rd party analytics tools to measure usage of our application to improve our services.
How to create an account
Click signup on 
phoenix.arize.com
. We offer logins via Google, Github, and email. This account will use the same account credentials as your Arize account if you have one.
Tracing: How to send in your first trace
Get your API keys from your Phoenix application on the left hand side. 
Here's the full sample code for LlamaIndex and OpenAI instrumentation. You can see all of our automatic tracing options 
here
.
LlamaIndex
OpenAI

Can I persistdata in the notbook?
You can persist data in the notebook by either setting the 
use_temp_dir
 flag to false in 
px.launch_app
 which will persit your data in SQLite on your disk at the 
PHOENIX_WORKING_DIR
. Alternatively you can deploy a phoenix instance and point to it via 
PHOENIX_COLLECTOR_ENDPOINT
.
Can I use gRPC for trace collection?
Phoenix does natively support gRPC for trace collection post 4.0 release. See 
How to configure phoenix
 for details.

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/deployment/persistence
title: Persistence

Persistence
Phoenix is backed by a SQL database. By default, if you run phoenix with no configuration, it uses SQLite. However you can also configure Phoenix to use PostgreSQL as the backend database as well.
Persistence is only available for 'arize-phoenix>=4.0.0'
Persistence for notebooks (a.k.a. 
launch_app
) is disabled by default. To enable persistence in notebooks, set the 
use_temp_dir
 to false.
SQLite
By default Phoenix uses SQLite so that it runs with no external dependancies. This SQLite instance is by default mounted in the directory specified by the 
PHOENIX_WORKING_DIR
 environment variable (default value in your home directory, e.x. 
~/.phoenix/
). The easiest way to make Phoenix to persist data is to back this working directory to a mounted volume. Attach the mounted volume to the phoenix pod and point 
PHOENIX_WORKING_DIR
 to that volume (e.x. 
/mnt/volume
)\
PostgreSQL
Phoenix also can natively be backed by PostgreSQL. To make Phoenix talk to PostgreSQL instead of SQLite, you will have to set the 
PHOENIX_SQL_DATABASE_URL
 to your PostgreSQL instance.

Spans can be nested, as is implied by the presence of a parent span ID: child spans represent sub-operations. This allows spans to more accurately capture the work done in an application.
Traces
A trace records the paths taken by requests (made by an application or end-user) as they propagate through multiple steps.
Without tracing, it is challenging to pinpoint the cause of performance problems in a system.
It improves the visibility of our application or system‚Äôs health and lets us debug behavior that is difficult to reproduce locally. Tracing is essential for LLM applications, which commonly have nondeterministic problems or are too complicated to reproduce locally.
Tracing makes debugging and understanding LLM applications less daunting by breaking down what happens within a request as it flows through a system.
A trace is made of one or more spans. The first span represents the root span. Each root span represents a request from start to finish. The spans underneath the parent provide a more in-depth context of what occurs during a request (or what steps make up a request).
Projects
A 
project
 is a collection of traces. You can think of a project as a container for all the traces that are related to a single application or service. You can have multiple projects, and each project can have multiple traces. Projects can be useful for various use-cases such as separating out environments, logging traces for evaluation runs, etc. To learn more about how to setup projects,  see the 
how-to guide.
Span Kind
When a span is created,  it is created as one of the following: Chain, Retriever, Reranker, LLM, Embedding, Agent, or Tool. 
CHAIN
A Chain is a starting point or a link between different LLM application steps. For example, a Chain span could be used to represent the beginning of a request to an LLM application or the glue code that passes context from a retriever to and LLM call.
RETRIEVER
A Retriever is a span that represents a data retrieval step. For example, a Retriever span could be used to represent a call to a vector store or a database.
RERANKER
A Reranker is a span that represents the reranking of a set of input documents. For example, a cross-encoder may be used to compute the input documents' relevance scores with respect to a user query, and the top K documents with the highest scores are then returned by the Reranker.
LLM
An LLM is a span that represents a call to an LLM. For example, an LLM span could be used to represent a call to OpenAI or Llama.
EMBEDDING
An Embedding is a span that represents a call to an LLM for an embedding. For example, an Embedding span could be used to represent a call OpenAI to get an ada-2 embedding for retrieval.
TOOL
A Tool is a span that represents a call to an external tool such as a calculator or a weather API.
AGENT
A span that encompasses calls to LLMs and Tools. An agent describes a reasoning block that acts on tools using the guidance of an LLM.

Span Attributes
Attributes are key-value pairs that contain metadata that you can use to annotate a span to carry information about the operation it is tracking.
For example, if a span invokes an LLM, you can capture the model name, the invocation parameters, the token count, and so on.
Attributes have the following rules:
Keys must be non-null string values
Values must be a non-null string, boolean, floating point value, integer, or an array of these values Additionally, there are Semantic Attributes, which are known naming conventions for metadata that is typically present in common operations. It's helpful to use semantic attribute naming wherever possible so that common kinds of metadata are standardized across systems. See 
semantic conventions
 for more information.

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/tracing/llm-traces
title: Overview: Tracing

Overview: Tracing
Tracing the execution of LLM applications using Telemetry
LLM tracing records the paths taken by requests as they propagate through multiple steps or components of an LLM application. For example, when a user interacts with an LLM application, tracing can capture the sequence of operations, such as document retrieval, embedding generation, language model invocation, and response generation to provide a detailed timeline of the request's execution.
Tracing is a helpful tool for understanding how your LLM application works. Phoenix offers comprehensive tracing capabilities that are not tied to any specific LLM vendor or framework. Phoenix accepts traces over the OpenTelemetry protocol (OTLP) and supports first-class instrumentation for a variety of frameworks ( 
LlamaIndex
, 
LangChain
,
 DSPy
),  SDKs (
OpenAI
, 
Bedrock
, 
Mistral
, 
Vertex
), and Languages. (Python, Javascript, etc.)
Using Phoenix's tracing capabilities can provide important insights into the inner workings of your LLM application. By analyzing the collected trace data, you can identify and address various performance and operational issues and improve the overall reliability and efficiency of your system.
Application Latency
: Identify and address slow invocations of LLMs, Retrievers, and other components within your application, enabling you to optimize performance and responsiveness.
Token Usage
: Gain a detailed breakdown of token usage for your LLM calls, allowing you to identify and optimize the most expensive LLM invocations.
Runtime Exceptions
: Capture and inspect critical runtime exceptions, such as rate-limiting events, that can help you proactively address and mitigate potential issues.
Retrieved Documents
: Inspect the documents retrieved during a Retriever call, including the score and order in which they were returned to provide insight into the retrieval process.
Embeddings
: Examine the embedding text used for retrieval and the underlying embedding model to allow you to validate and refine your embedding strategies.
LLM Parameters
: Inspect the parameters used when calling an LLM, such as temperature and system prompts, to ensure optimal configuration and debugging.
Prompt Templates
: Understand the prompt templates used during the prompting step and the variables that were applied, allowing you to fine-tune and improve your prompting strategies.
Tool Descriptions
: View the descriptions and function signatures of the tools your LLM has been given access to in order to better understand and control your LLM‚Äôs capabilities.
LLM Function Calls
: For LLMs with function call capabilities (e.g., OpenAI), you can inspect the function selection and function messages in the input to the LLM, further improving your ability to debug and optimize your application.
By using tracing in Phoenix, you can gain increased visibility into your LLM application, empowering you to identify and address performance bottlenecks, optimize resource utilization, and ensure the overall reliability and effectiveness of your system.
View the inner workings for your LLM Application
To get started, check out the 
Quickstart guide
After that, read through the 
Concepts Section
 to get and understanding of the different components.
If you want to learn how to accomplish a particular task, check out the 
How-To Guides.

A Reranker is a span that represents the reranking of a set of input documents. For example, a cross-encoder may be used to compute the input documents' relevance scores with respect to a user query, and the top K documents with the highest scores are then returned by the Reranker.
LLM
An LLM is a span that represents a call to an LLM. For example, an LLM span could be used to represent a call to OpenAI or Llama.
EMBEDDING
An Embedding is a span that represents a call to an LLM for an embedding. For example, an Embedding span could be used to represent a call OpenAI to get an ada-2 embedding for retrieval.
TOOL
A Tool is a span that represents a call to an external tool such as a calculator or a weather API.
AGENT
A span that encompasses calls to LLMs and Tools. An agent describes a reasoning block that acts on tools using the guidance of an LLM.

Span Attributes
Attributes are key-value pairs that contain metadata that you can use to annotate a span to carry information about the operation it is tracking.
For example, if a span invokes an LLM, you can capture the model name, the invocation parameters, the token count, and so on.
Attributes have the following rules:
Keys must be non-null string values
Values must be a non-null string, boolean, floating point value, integer, or an array of these values Additionally, there are Semantic Attributes, which are known naming conventions for metadata that is typically present in common operations. It's helpful to use semantic attribute naming wherever possible so that common kinds of metadata are standardized across systems. See 
semantic conventions
 for more information.

source: https://docs.arize.com/phoenix/tracing/llm-traces
title: Overview: Tracing

Overview: Tracing
Tracing the execution of LLM applications using Telemetry
LLM tracing records the paths taken by requests as they propagate through multiple steps or components of an LLM application. For example, when a user interacts with an LLM application, tracing can capture the sequence of operations, such as document retrieval, embedding generation, language model invocation, and response generation to provide a detailed timeline of the request's execution.
Tracing is a helpful tool for understanding how your LLM application works. Phoenix offers comprehensive tracing capabilities that are not tied to any specific LLM vendor or framework. Phoenix accepts traces over the OpenTelemetry protocol (OTLP) and supports first-class instrumentation for a variety of frameworks ( 
LlamaIndex
, 
LangChain
,
 DSPy
),  SDKs (
OpenAI
, 
Bedrock
, 
Mistral
, 
Vertex
), and Languages. (Python, Javascript, etc.)
Using Phoenix's tracing capabilities can provide important insights into the inner workings of your LLM application. By analyzing the collected trace data, you can identify and address various performance and operational issues and improve the overall reliability and efficiency of your system.
Application Latency
: Identify and address slow invocations of LLMs, Retrievers, and other components within your application, enabling you to optimize performance and responsiveness.
Token Usage
: Gain a detailed breakdown of token usage for your LLM calls, allowing you to identify and optimize the most expensive LLM invocations.
Runtime Exceptions
: Capture and inspect critical runtime exceptions, such as rate-limiting events, that can help you proactively address and mitigate potential issues.
Retrieved Documents
: Inspect the documents retrieved during a Retriever call, including the score and order in which they were returned to provide insight into the retrieval process.
Embeddings
: Examine the embedding text used for retrieval and the underlying embedding model to allow you to validate and refine your embedding strategies.
LLM Parameters
: Inspect the parameters used when calling an LLM, such as temperature and system prompts, to ensure optimal configuration and debugging.
Prompt Templates
: Understand the prompt templates used during the prompting step and the variables that were applied, allowing you to fine-tune and improve your prompting strategies.
Tool Descriptions
: View the descriptions and function signatures of the tools your LLM has been given access to in order to better understand and control your LLM‚Äôs capabilities.
LLM Function Calls
: For LLMs with function call capabilities (e.g., OpenAI), you can inspect the function selection and function messages in the input to the LLM, further improving your ability to debug and optimize your application.
By using tracing in Phoenix, you can gain increased visibility into your LLM application, empowering you to identify and address performance bottlenecks, optimize resource utilization, and ensure the overall reliability and effectiveness of your system.
View the inner workings for your LLM Application
To get started, check out the 
Quickstart guide
After that, read through the 
Concepts Section
 to get and understanding of the different components.
If you want to learn how to accomplish a particular task, check out the 
How-To Guides.

output_messages:
[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "Sure! Here are the recommended parameters for running ProteinMPNN with your PDB content:

1. **ca_only**: `True`
2. **use_soluble_model**: `False`
3. **num_seq_per_target**: `10`
4. **sampling_temp**: `0.1`

And now, let's go through each of these parameters to explain why I've chosen them:

### 1. ca_only setting: `True`
In your PDB content, we see only backbone atoms listed for each residue (namely, N, CA, C, and O for Glycine). The `ca_only` parameter set to `True` tells ProteinMPNN to focus only on alpha carbon (`CA`) coordinates to predict the protein sequences. This is often used when you have high-resolution structures where side chain data might be missing or unnecessary for initial predictions.

### 2. use_soluble_model: `False`
The choice between using a soluble versus a membrane model depends significantly on the type of protein you‚Äôre analyzing. Since no specific mention of membrane-binding properties is indicated in your snippet, and given that default practices favor the general model due to its wide applicability, setting `use_soluble_model` to `False` is appropriate. This utilizes the general-purpose model, likely offering better cross-model predictions for various protein contexts.

### 3. num_seq_per_target: `10`
The `num_seq_per_target` parameter dictates how many sequence predictions you want to generate for each structure. A value of `10` is a good starting point. It balances computation time and diversity of results, providing a wide enough pool of sequence possibilities without being overwhelmingly large. This number enables you to identify high-confidence predictions while still exploring a range of possible sequences.

### 4. sampling_temp: `0.1`
The `sampling_temp` parameter controls the stochastic aspect of sequence generation. Lower values lead to less randomization, focusing on predicted patterns. A sampling temperature of `0.1` means the model will give you predictions with a bit of variety but leaning heavily on the most probable sequences. It's suitable for early iterations when you'd like to see likely sequences first before considering more diversity.

Feel free to reach out for more details or any further questions!"}]

input_input:
1. **ca_only**: `True`
2. **use_soluble_model**: `False`
3. **num_seq_per_target**: `10`
4. **sampling_temp**: `0.1`

And now, let's go through each of these parameters to explain why I've chosen them:

### 1. ca_only setting: `True`
In your PDB content, we see only backbone atoms listed for each residue (namely, N, CA, C, and O for Glycine). The `ca_only` parameter set to `True` tells ProteinMPNN to focus only on alpha carbon (`CA`) coordinates to predict the protein sequences. This is often used when you have high-resolution structures where side chain data might be missing or unnecessary for initial predictions.

### 2. use_soluble_model: `False`
The choice between using a soluble versus a membrane model depends significantly on the type of protein you‚Äôre analyzing. Since no specific mention of membrane-binding properties is indicated in your snippet, and given that default practices favor the general model due to its wide applicability, setting `use_soluble_model` to `False` is appropriate. This utilizes the general-purpose model, likely offering better cross-model predictions for various protein contexts.

### 3. num_seq_per_target: `10`
The `num_seq_per_target` parameter dictates how many sequence predictions you want to generate for each structure. A value of `10` is a good starting point. It balances computation time and diversity of results, providing a wide enough pool of sequence possibilities without being overwhelmingly large. This number enables you to identify high-confidence predictions while still exploring a range of possible sequences.

### 4. sampling_temp: `0.1`
The `sampling_temp` parameter controls the stochastic aspect of sequence generation. Lower values lead to less randomization, focusing on predicted patterns. A sampling temperature of `0.1` means the model will give you predictions with a bit of variety but leaning heavily on the most probable sequences. It's suitable for early iterations when you'd like to see likely sequences first before considering more diversity.

Feel free to reach out for more details or any further questions!

        3. diffusion_steps: [value]

        Keep the explanation natural and suitable for voice output.

        HEADER    IMMUNE SYSTEM                           24-JAN-01   1HZH              
TITLE     CRYSTAL STRUCTURE OF THE INTACT HUMAN IGG B12 WITH BROAD AND POTENT   
TITLE    2 ACTIVITY AGAINST PRIMARY HIV-1 ISOLATES: A TEMPLATE FOR HIV VACCINE  
TITLE    3 DESIGN                                                               
COMPND    MOL_ID: 1;                                                            
COMPND   2 MOLECULE: IMMUNOGLOBULIN HEAVY CHAIN;                                
COMPND   3 CHA...
        '}]
output_messages:
[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "PARAMETERS:
1. contigs: 'A20-60/0 50-100'
2. hotspot_res: 'H:55, L:100'
3. diffusion_steps: '200'

EXPLANATION:
Let's break down how these parameters would work in RFdiffusion for designing with the given PDB structure, which is an intact human immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody. The 'contigs' parameter specifies the range of amino acid segments to be considered in the design. Here, 'A20-60/0 50-100' indicates we're targeting a segment that spans residues 20 to 60 in a chain, and also focusing on a possible flexible region or linker of lengths 50 to 100. This allows us to consider both the specificity needed for binding, given the nature of antibodies, and an acceptable range of binder length variations.

For 'hotspot_res', I've chosen residues based on typical locations of antibody-antigen interactions. These are general suggestions assuming you might be interested in the complementarity-determining region (CDR) of the heavy chain ('H:55') and light chain ('L:100'), although these can be refined based on specific antigen interactions or structural insights.

Finally, 'diffusion_steps', set to 200, provides a balance between computational efficiency and the thorough exploration of conformational space, which is especially important in achieving a stable design with complex structures like antibodies. This straightforward explanation aims to align technical decisions with their practical implications, ensuring the protein design process is both effective and efficient."}]

input_input:
Let's break down how these parameters would work in RFdiffusion for designing with the given PDB structure, which is an intact human immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody. The 'contigs' parameter specifies the range of amino acid segments to be considered in the design. Here, 'A20-60/0 50-100' indicates we're targeting a segment that spans residues 20 to 60 in a chain, and also focusing on a possible flexible region or linker of lengths 50 to 100. This allows us to consider both the specificity needed for binding, given the nature of antibodies, and an acceptable range of binder length variations.

For 'hotspot_res', I've chosen residues based on typical locations of antibody-antigen interactions. These are general suggestions assuming you might be interested in the complementarity-determining region (CDR) of the heavy chain ('H:55') and light chain ('L:100'), although these can be refined based on specific antigen interactions or structural insights.

Finally, 'diffusion_steps', set to 200, provides a balance between computational efficiency and the thorough exploration of conformational space, which is especially important in achieving a stable design with complex structures like antibodies. This straightforward explanation aims to align technical decisions with their practical implications, ensuring the protein design process is both effective and efficient.

2. hotspot_res: 35, 52, 66
3. diffusion_steps: 1000

EXPLANATION:
Given the PDB structure of hen egg-white lysozyme, a well-studied enzyme, we need to choose parameters that accommodate the entire protein while providing flexibility for potential modifications. The lysozyme has 129 amino acids. For contigs, we have set 'A1-129/0 20-40'. The first part 'A1-129' represents the full sequence of the chain, ensuring the target is covered entirely from start to finish. The '/0' represents that we are not specifying any chain break, and '20-40' allows for a flexible design binder length, which facilitates incorporating significant modifications or additional functional segments ranging from 20 to 40 amino acids.

For hotspot residues, we choose key active site and structurally crucial residues such as 35, 52, and 66, which are often involved in the protein's enzymatic activity or stability. By setting these as hotspots, we aim to preserve or enhance important functional sites during diffusion-based design.

Diffusion steps are set to 1000, providing sufficient iterations to explore a broad conformational space for substantial sequence and structural optimization. This step count balances computational efficiency with the need for thorough sampling, enabling the preservation of essential enzymatic characteristics while allowing room for innovative enhancements.

Overall, these parameters are aimed at reliably probing new structural variants of lysozyme while maintaining its biological function and ensuring flexibility for computational design applications."}]

input_input:
Given the PDB structure of hen egg-white lysozyme, a well-studied enzyme, we need to choose parameters that accommodate the entire protein while providing flexibility for potential modifications. The lysozyme has 129 amino acids. For contigs, we have set 'A1-129/0 20-40'. The first part 'A1-129' represents the full sequence of the chain, ensuring the target is covered entirely from start to finish. The '/0' represents that we are not specifying any chain break, and '20-40' allows for a flexible design binder length, which facilitates incorporating significant modifications or additional functional segments ranging from 20 to 40 amino acids.

For hotspot residues, we choose key active site and structurally crucial residues such as 35, 52, and 66, which are often involved in the protein's enzymatic activity or stability. By setting these as hotspots, we aim to preserve or enhance important functional sites during diffusion-based design.

Diffusion steps are set to 1000, providing sufficient iterations to explore a broad conformational space for substantial sequence and structural optimization. This step count balances computational efficiency with the need for thorough sampling, enabling the preservation of essential enzymatic characteristics while allowing room for innovative enhancements.

Overall, these parameters are aimed at reliably probing new structural variants of lysozyme while maintaining its biological function and ensuring flexibility for computational design applications.

        Analyze the following PDB content and suggest appropriate parameters for running ProteinMPNN:

        ATOM      1  N   GLY A   1      28.387   8.876  22.027  1.00  0.00
ATOM      2  CA  GLY A   1      27.477   8.701  20.902  1.00  0.00
ATOM      3  C   GLY A   1      28.219   8.221  19.662  1.00  0.00
ATOM      4  O   GLY A   1      27.682   7.453  18.863  1.00  0.00
ATOM      5  N   GLY A   2      29.476   8.450  19.612  1.00  0.00
ATOM      6  CA  GLY A   2      30.310   8.036  18.490  1.00  0.00
ATOM      7  C   GLY A   2      30.502   6.525  18.474  1.00  0.00
ATOM      8  O   GLY A   2     ...

        Provide the following parameters:
        1. ca_only
        2. use_soluble_model
        3. num_seq_per_target
        4. sampling_temp

        Explain your reasoning for each parameter.
        '}]
output_messages:
[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "To suggest appropriate parameters for running ProteinMPNN on the provided PDB content, let's examine each parameter individually and consider the nature of the input data:

1. **ca_only:**
   - **Explanation:** The `ca_only` parameter is used when the input contains only C-alpha (CA) atoms rather than the full atom detail of the backbone (N, CA, C, O). By examining the provided PDB content, we see that it includes all standard backbone atoms (N, CA, C, O) for at least two residues.
   - **Recommended Value:** `False` because the PDB data includes full backbone atoms and not just C-alpha atoms.

2. **use_soluble_model:**
   - **Explanation:** The choice between using a soluble model or a different model variant typically depends on the expected environment of the protein. If the protein is expected to function in a soluble environment (e.g., cytoplasm), the soluble model is advised.
   - **Recommended Value:** Given that no specific contextual information about the protein's environment is present in the provided PDB file, a default assumption would be to choose a soluble protein model, which is a common scenario.
   - **Recommended Value:** `True` to use the soluble model unless additional information suggests a membrane or insoluble context.

3. **num_seq_per_target:**
   - **Explanation:** This parameter specifies how many sequences you wish to sample for your target protein. The higher the number, the more diverse sequences you will generate, which can be useful for exploring sequence space.
   - **Recommended Value:** The choice here is often dependent on computational resources and desired assessment depth. A moderate number like `10` can provide a decent diversity without being overly computationally expensive.

output_messages:
[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "To suggest appropriate parameters for running ProteinMPNN on the provided PDB content, it's crucial to understand the context and intent of using ProteinMPNN. Given that we have only a partial list of residues and details of two consecutive glycine residues, here are some suggested parameters and their rationale:

1. **ca_only**: `False`
   - **Rationale**: The provided PDB content includes all backbone atoms (N, CA, C, and O) for glycine residues. The `ca_only` option is typically used when the PDB file only includes alpha carbon (CA) positions and not the full backbone. Since you have the full backbone available, it's preferable to use the complete information to achieve more accurate modeling.

2. **use_soluble_model**: `True` or `False`
   - **Rationale**: The choice of using a soluble model depends on whether the protein or peptide in this PDB file is soluble. Glycine residues are flexible and are often found in loops or flexible regions. Without additional context, it's not clear if this is part of a soluble protein or part of a membrane-associated structure. If you're modeling a typical soluble protein, set this to `True`. If you know it's membrane-associated, opt for `False`.

3. **num_seq_per_target**: `10` (or adjust based on computational resources and needs)
   - **Rationale**: The number of sequences per target depends on the diversity and quantity of designed sequences you want. A setting of `10` is a reasonable starting point as it provides diversity without excessive computational demand. You may increase this number if you have specific requirements for exploring a wider variety of sequences.

4. **sampling_temp**: `0.1` to `0.5`
   - **Rationale**: Sampling temperature affects the diversity and convergence of the sequences generated. A lower temperature (closer to `0.1`) means more deterministic design with less variability among sequences. A higher temperature (`0.5` or higher) introduces more variability and allows exploration of a broader conformational space. Begin with a moderate range to balance diversity and convergence, adjusting based on design goals and observed results.

These parameters can be adjusted based on specific experimental needs or additional context about the protein's function, environment, or design objectives."}]

[{'role': 'system', 'content': "You are an expert in RFdiffusion parameter optimization. 
                Always ensure contigs parameter has both target specification AND binder length range after /0.
                Example: 'A20-60/0 50-100' NOT just 'A20-60/0'"}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "
        Analyze this PDB content and suggest basic parameters for RFdiffusion that will work reliably.
        Only provide the following required parameters:
        1. contigs: Must be in format 'chainID-range/0 binder_length_range'. 
           Example: 'A20-60/0 50-100' means:
           - Keep amino acids 20-60 in Chain A as target
           - /0 marks the end of target chain
           - Generate a binder protein of length 50-100 amino acids
        2. hotspot_res: List three sequential residues from the middle of the chain
        3. diffusion_steps: Use minimum value of 15 for faster results
        
        Keep the parameters simple and conservative to ensure API success.
        Base the analysis on this PDB structure:
        HEADER    LIGASE/RNA                              15-SEP-93   1GTS              
TITLE     STRUCTURAL BASIS FOR TRANSFER RNA AMINOACEYLATION BY ESCHERICHIA COLI 
TITLE    2 GLUTAMINYL-TRNA SYNTHETASE                                           
COMPND    MOL_ID: 1;                                                            
COMPND   2 MOLECULE: TRNAGLN;                                                   
COMPND   3 CHAIN: B;                                                            
COMPND   4 MOL...
        "}]

1. **contigs**: Since you have a molecule (likely tRNA or a protein interacting with tRNA) in Chain B, you can assume a typical continuous stretch. For example, use:  
   `'B15-45/0 50-100'`  
   This means amino acids 15 to 45 in Chain B are part of the target structure, and the binder length range to be generated is between 50 and 100 amino acids.

2. **hotspot_res**: Choose three sequential residues from the middle of the Chain B. Assuming this chain has more than 45 residues, you might select residues:  
   `hotspot_res: B30, B31, B32`

3. **diffusion_steps**: Use the minimum recommended value:  
   `diffusion_steps: 15`

These parameters are designed to optimize RFdiffusion for generating a binder to the specified target region effectively and quickly."}]

input_input:
Let's dive into the rationale behind selecting these parameters for the RFdiffusion run. First off, looking at the structure, we have a transfer RNA (tRNA) molecule in complex with glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase. The chain of interest is chain B, where the tRNA is located. This type of complex requires a focus on both the target specificity (the enzyme) and a proper binding length of the RNA.

For the contigs parameter, I chose 'A20-200/0 150-300'. This includes a wide range of potential target sequences on the enzyme side, from 20 to 200 amino acids, and for the associated RNA binding section, a slightly narrower range of 150 to 300 nucleotides. The use of 'A20-200/0 150-300' ensures that we have not only the flexibility to evolve different regions of the protein with appropriate length but also cater to the functional binding with the RNA, reflecting the biological function of transferring amino acids accurately.

Next, the hotspot residues are assigned to specific positions in the tRNA (chain B) that are likely critical for enzyme interaction, namely B:10, B:30, and B:50. These positions are often integral to maintaining the structure and function of tRNA during aminoacylation processes.

Finally, diffusion_steps is set to 200. This is a moderate number, aimed at providing sufficient iterations for sampling while preventing excessive computation time. This setting ensures that the diffusion process can explore the conformational space adequately, allowing for variations that improve or retain the functional characteristics of the enzyme-RNA interaction.

By combining these parameters, RFdiffusion will have a guided yet sufficiently exploratory runway to generate new, plausible designs while respecting the complex's biological purpose.

        Explain your reasoning for each parameter.
        '}]

[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "Certainly! Let's analyze the provided PDB content and determine the appropriate parameters for running ProteinMPNN:

### PDB Content Analysis:
The PDB content provided consists of atoms from a protein chain, labeled with chain identifier 'A'. The residues are listed sequentially and include atomic coordinates. The specific sequence of residues highlighted appears to be composed solely of Glycine residues.

### Suggested Parameters for ProteinMPNN:

1. **ca_only:**
   - **Value:** `False`
   - **Reasoning:** The `ca_only` parameter in ProteinMPNN determines whether only C-alpha (CA) atoms are used for structure representation. Since you provided a full atomic representation (including backbone atoms like N, CA, C, and O), setting `ca_only` to `False` is suitable because it allows the use of detailed atomic data, which can potentially lead to more accurate modeling.

2. **use_soluble_model:**
   - **Value:** `True` or `False` (Context-Dependent)
   - **Reasoning:** The `use_soluble_model` parameter should be set according to the environment in which you expect this protein to function. If this protein is mainly expressed or functions in a soluble environment (e.g., cytoplasm), you would typically set `use_soluble_model` to `True`. If it is a membrane protein or part of insoluble complexes, `False` might be more appropriate. If no contextual information is provided, defaulting to `True` for general use is a safe choice.

3. **num_seq_per_target:**
   - **Value:** `10` (for initial exploration)
   - **Reasoning:** The `num_seq_per_target` parameter specifies the number of sequence predictions or designs generated per structure. Starting with a moderate number like 10 gives a balanced initial sample of sequences for evaluation without overwhelming computational resources. Depending on the results, you can adjust higher to explore more diverse sequences.

4. **sampling_temp:**
   - **Value:** `0.1` to `0.3`
   - **Reasoning:** The `sampling_temp` parameter controls the diversity of the generated sequences; lower values result in sequences closer to the most likely prediction while higher values allow more exploration and diversity. A value of `0.1` to `0.3` is a typical starting point, ensuring that the diversity is reasonable while still being relatively focused on high-probability sequences.

### Conclusion:
These parameters are chosen based on the given PDB structure and typical use cases for ProteinMPNN. Adjust the parameters further based on the specific biological context, computational resources, or after evaluating preliminary results."}]

        Analyze the following PDB content and suggest appropriate parameters for running ProteinMPNN:

        ATOM      1  N   GLY A   1      -7.161   1.641 -19.813  1.00  0.00
ATOM      2  CA  GLY A   1      -7.289   0.193 -19.927  1.00  0.00
ATOM      3  C   GLY A   1      -6.237  -0.520 -19.088  1.00  0.00
ATOM      4  O   GLY A   1      -5.146   0.006 -18.863  1.00  0.00
ATOM      5  N   GLY A   2      -6.620  -1.470 -18.394  1.00  0.00
ATOM      6  CA  GLY A   2      -5.691  -2.169 -17.514  1.00  0.00
ATOM      7  C   GLY A   2      -4.499  -2.712 -18.292  1.00  0.00
ATOM      8  O   GLY A   2     ...

        Provide the following parameters:
        1. ca_only
        2. use_soluble_model
        3. num_seq_per_target
        4. sampling_temp

        Explain your reasoning for each parameter.

output_messages:
[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "To determine the appropriate parameters for running ProteinMPNN on the given PDB content, let's analyze the structure and apply that knowledge to each parameter:

1. **ca_only**:
   - The provided PDB content includes full atomic coordinates, with entries for nitrogen (N), carbon alpha (CA), carbon (C), and oxygen (O) atoms. This suggests that both backbone and side chain data might be available. However, often only the CA atoms are used if a simplified model is sufficient or if focusing on folding patterns and backbones is the goal.
   - **Recommendation**: `ca_only = False`. This is because while the provided snippet only explicitly shows a few atoms, if more comprehensive data is available, using the entire backbone can potentially yield more precise results unless there are memory constraints or specific simplicity needs.

2. **use_soluble_model**:
   - This parameter is used for distinguishing between proteins expected to function in soluble environments versus others, like membrane proteins. Without specific environmental context suggesting a membrane localization, and given that glycine-rich sequences commonly appear in soluble proteins, it's generally safe to use a soluble model.
   - **Recommendation**: `use_soluble_model = True`. Given the lack of context suggesting otherwise, and the fact simple glycine structures are commonly found in soluble environments.

3. **num_seq_per_target**:
   - This parameter determines how many sequence variations are generated for the target structure. More sequences provide better insights into variability and potential function but increase computational demands.
   - **Recommendation**: `num_seq_per_target = 10`. This is a balanced number that provides sufficient diversity for most analyses without overloading computational resources, assuming this is a preliminary analysis. This number can be increased if further exploration is required.

4. **sampling_temp**:
   - The sampling temperature affects how much diversity is introduced in the generated sequences. Higher temperatures allow for more variations, but can lead to less native-like predictions.
   - **Recommendation**: `sampling_temp = 0.1`. A lower value is often used for refinement and accuracy-focused tasks, ensuring the generated sequences are close to native-like conformations. This assumes an interest in accuracy over exploration; if exploring diverse sequences is of interest, this can be increased.

The above recommendations are based on typical scenarios and may be fine-tuned with additional context or specific objectives for the protein analyses. If computational resources allow, experimenting with different parameters might give deeper insights."}]

ATOM      8  O   GLY A   2     ...

[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': "**Parameters:**

1. `ca_only`: **False**
2. `use_soluble_model`: **Not explicitly recommended**, assess hydrophobicity and context
3. `num_seq_per_target`: **20**
4. `sampling_temp`: **0.1**

---

Hello! Let's dive into how we might configure ProteinMPNN to analyze the structure you've provided.

First up, the `ca_only` setting: this parameter determines whether the model should consider only the alpha carbon (CA) atoms of the protein backbone, or utilize all atom positions provided in the PDB file. In your case, the PDB data you've provided includes detailed atomic information, not just the alpha carbons. Using `ca_only: False` allows the model to leverage this comprehensive structure data, giving it more context about the protein's geometry and potentially improving accuracy in modeling interactions and structure.

Next is the `use_soluble_model` option, which would determine if a model optimized for soluble proteins should be used. To pinpoint whether this applies, you need to consider the protein's intrinsic properties and its environment. If the protein is part of a membrane or is an integral membrane protein, you may want a model fine-tuned for that context instead. Given just the snippet of structure, a decision here isn't explicit unless further biochemical context suggests solubility. So, generally, you might default to the context inferred from any additional biological information about the protein.

Then, let‚Äôs talk about `num_seq_per_target`. This parameter indicates how many sequences you'd like the model to generate per target structure. Setting this to about **20** strikes a good balance between getting a variety of sequences to explore the diversity of potential interactions and keeping computational demands reasonable. It's often enough to provide insightful variations without overwhelming analysis requirements.

Lastly, for `sampling_temp`, this parameter affects the randomness of sequence sampling ‚Äî akin to how 'explorative' the model should be. A lower temperature like **0.1** encourages the generation of sequences that are more energetically favorable or stable, essentially prioritizing quality over variety. This low temperature is a reasonable starting point if you're looking for reliable sequences that are more likely to maintain the structural integrity of your protein when you're inferring structure-function relationships.

Hopefully, this gives you a clear pathway to setting up your ProteinMPNN run optimally for analyzing that intriguing protein structure! Let me know if you need any further explanation or additional parameters."}]

input_input:
1. `ca_only`: **False**
2. `use_soluble_model`: **Not explicitly recommended**, assess hydrophobicity and context
3. `num_seq_per_target`: **20**
4. `sampling_temp`: **0.1**

---

Hello! Let's dive into how we might configure ProteinMPNN to analyze the structure you've provided.

First up, the `ca_only` setting: this parameter determines whether the model should consider only the alpha carbon (CA) atoms of the protein backbone, or utilize all atom positions provided in the PDB file. In your case, the PDB data you've provided includes detailed atomic information, not just the alpha carbons. Using `ca_only: False` allows the model to leverage this comprehensive structure data, giving it more context about the protein's geometry and potentially improving accuracy in modeling interactions and structure.

Next is the `use_soluble_model` option, which would determine if a model optimized for soluble proteins should be used. To pinpoint whether this applies, you need to consider the protein's intrinsic properties and its environment. If the protein is part of a membrane or is an integral membrane protein, you may want a model fine-tuned for that context instead. Given just the snippet of structure, a decision here isn't explicit unless further biochemical context suggests solubility. So, generally, you might default to the context inferred from any additional biological information about the protein.

Then, let‚Äôs talk about `num_seq_per_target`. This parameter indicates how many sequences you'd like the model to generate per target structure. Setting this to about **20** strikes a good balance between getting a variety of sequences to explore the diversity of potential interactions and keeping computational demands reasonable. It's often enough to provide insightful variations without overwhelming analysis requirements.

Lastly, for `sampling_temp`, this parameter affects the randomness of sequence sampling ‚Äî akin to how 'explorative' the model should be. A lower temperature like **0.1** encourages the generation of sequences that are more energetically favorable or stable, essentially prioritizing quality over variety. This low temperature is a reasonable starting point if you're looking for reliable sequences that are more likely to maintain the structural integrity of your protein when you're inferring structure-function relationships.

Hopefully, this gives you a clear pathway to setting up your ProteinMPNN run optimally for analyzing that intriguing protein structure! Let me know if you need any further explanation or additional parameters.

input_messages:
[{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are an expert in molecular generation and optimization using MolMIM.'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': '
        Analyze the following SMILES string and suggest appropriate parameters for running MolMIM:

        CN1C=C(C2=CC=CC=C21)C3=NC(=NC=C3)NC4=C(C=C(C(=C4)NC(=O)C=C)N(C)CCN(C)C)OC

        Provide the following parameters:
        1. algorithm
        2. num_molecules
        3. property_name
        4. minimize
        5. min_similarity
        6. particles
        7. iterations

        Explain your reasoning for each parameter.
        '}]
output_messages:
[{'role': 'assistant', 'content': 'To analyze the given SMILES string and suggest appropriate parameters for running MolMIM, we should first understand the nature of the molecule and the potential goals of its optimization. The SMILES string provided:

```
CN1C=C(C2=CC=CC=C21)C3=NC(=NC=C3)NC4=C(C=C(C(=C4)NC(=O)C=C)N(C)CCN(C)C)OC
```

corresponds to a complex structure featuring multiple rings and functionalities. Let's consider the parameters:

1. **Algorithm**: The choice of algorithm largely depends on the optimization goals, such as optimizing molecular properties or exploring chemical space. For complex polycyclic aromatic compounds like this one, using a genetic algorithm may be beneficial due to its robustness in exploring diverse chemical spaces and optimizing multiple properties simultaneously.

   **Suggested value**: `"genetic_algorithm"`

2. **Num_molecules**: This parameter defines how many new molecules you want to generate. Given the complexity of the parent molecule, a moderate number of molecules would be suitable to allow enough diversity while managing computational resources.

   **Suggested value**: `100`

3. **Property_name**: The property of interest should be directly related to the intended application of the molecule. Common properties include drug-likeness, solubility, binding affinity (if a target site is known), or a specific pharmacokinetic property. For a molecule with potential pharmaceutical applications, you might choose "binding affinity" if a target is known.

   **Suggested value**: `"binding_affinity"` (or another property relevant to your application)

4. **Minimize**: Whether to minimize or maximize the selected property depends on the property itself. For properties like energy, you typically minimize, whereas for affinity or logP, you might maximize to enhance interaction or solubility.

   **Suggested value**: `true` (if minimizing energy) / `false` (if maximizing binding affinity)

5. **Min_similarity**: This parameter sets the threshold for similarity to the original molecule, balancing exploration and exploitation. A typical value might range from 0.4 to 0.6 to retain some structural similarity but allow meaningful exploration.

   **Suggested value**: `0.5`

6. **Particles**: Particles represent the population size in optimization algorithms. A larger number allows more exploration but increases computational cost. For our molecule, a moderate particle size is recommended.

   **Suggested value**: `50`

7. **Iterations**: The number of optimization steps should be sufficient to allow convergence but not excessive to save computational resources. For complex molecules, more iterations might be necessary.

   **Suggested value**: `500`

Each of these parameters is selected to balance computational efficiency with the need to explore the chemical space thoroughly, depending on the specific goals of molecular optimization. Adjustments might be needed based on specific experimental goals or computational resources.'}]

1. **Algorithm**: Considering the complexity and functionalized nature of the molecule, a robust algorithm that can handle multiple objectives and complex molecule structures like "Genetic Algorithm" or "Simulated Annealing" is suitable for exploring a diverse chemical space and optimizing molecular properties efficiently.

2. **Num_molecules**: With the goal of exploring a variety of potential derivatives, setting this parameter to 100-200 can provide a sufficiently diverse set of analogues while being computationally feasible.

4. **Minimize**: To enhance properties like binding affinity or reduce molecular weight, minimize parameters related to steric hindrance or molecular size. Set this to `True` to ensure the algorithm will focus on optimizing these properties.

5. **Min_similarity**: Setting a moderate similarity threshold (e.g., 0.4 to 0.6) would be advantageous. This allows for exploration of novel chemical spaces while maintaining a degree of structural similarity to ensure that new molecules retain desired core structures or functionalities.

- Selecting appropriate properties to optimize and setting a suitable similarity threshold helps to target molecules that are both novel and relevant to the desired application.
- A sufficient number of iterations allows the algorithm to converge on optimized molecules within the set constraints and parameters efficiently.'}]

Here's a suggested set of parameters with reasoning:

1. **Algorithm**: Genetic Algorithm (GA)
    - **Reasoning**: Genetic algorithms are effective for exploring large chemical spaces with diverse structures, especially when dealing with complex organic molecules featuring multifaceted functional groups. They help in navigating through various possible mutations and recombinations to find optimal structures.

2. **Num_molecules**: 50-100
    - **Reasoning**: Starting with 50-100 molecules provides a good balance, offering sufficient diversity to explore the chemical space while being computationally manageable. This number serves as a reasonable starting point for generating diverse candidate molecules similar to the given structure.

3. **Property_name**: Drug-likeness or LogP
    - **Reasoning**: Given the presence of multiple aromatic rings and nitrogen atoms, assessing properties like drug-likeness (using Lipinski's Rule of Five) or LogP (partition coefficient) is crucial. These properties give insights into the potential pharmacokinetic and distribution properties of the molecule, important for medicinal chemistry applications.

4. **Minimize**: True
    - **Reasoning**: Setting this parameter to 'True' ensures that the generated molecules are geometry optimized, leading to stable and energetically favorable conformations. It's crucial for ensuring the molecules can realistically exist and for accurate property evaluations.

5. **Min_similarity**: 0.4-0.6
    - **Reasoning**: A moderate minimum similarity requirement balances the need to generate molecules that are both novel and maintain key structural features of the original molecule. This range allows for structural exploration while retaining essential moieties that could be critical to the molecule's function.

6. **Particles**: 20-30
    - **Reasoning**: Utilizing 20-30 particles provides sufficient parallel processes to explore multiple molecular pathways simultaneously, increasing the likelihood of identifying high-quality candidates. It's a good number for balancing computational efficiency and thoroughness in exploration of the chemical space.

7. **Iterations**: 1000-1500
    - **Reasoning**: A higher number of iterations (1000-1500) allows for adequate exploration and optimization of the chemical space, especially given the complexity of the molecule. It ensures that the algorithm has enough time to converge on potentially optimized structures that meet the desired properties.

These parameters are designed to guide MolMIM in efficiently exploring the chemical space related to the supplied SMILES string, while considering both structural complexity and potential functional applications."}]
